name: Laughing in the face of adversity
description: Comedy has been used by First Nations storytellers as a tool for social change. On our screens, humour invites audiences to engage with stories and prompts them to grapple with ideas that they otherwise might shy away from.

key_work.title: Basically Black
key_work.brief_description: Basically Black combined comedy, activism and performing arts while reflecting the political struggles and organising of 1960s and 70s Redfern. The first TV program written and performed by an all-Indigenous cast, this groundbreaking program tackled racism and white paternalism through humour.

constellations_primary.name: Laughing in the face of adversity
constellations_primary.description: Comedy has been used by First Nations storytellers as a tool for social change. On our screens, humour invites audiences to engage with stories and prompts them to grapple with ideas that they otherwise might shy away from.

constellations_other.name: Sequins and sapphires
constellations_other.description: Two of the most striking costumes on the big and small screens embody the glamour of leading First Peoples ladies.

constellations_other.name: Black Power through film and TV
constellations_other.description: The Black Power movement of the late 1960s and early 70s was “the most exciting and dynamic era in modern Indigenous history” according to Aboriginal activist Professor Gary Foley, who gained widespread attention for protests during the time and later leveraged film and TV to fight for Indigenous rights.

start.title: Basically Black
start.brief_description: Basically Black combined comedy, activism and performing arts while reflecting the political struggles and organising of 1960s and 70s Redfern. The first TV program written and performed by an all-Indigenous cast, this groundbreaking program tackled racism and white paternalism through humour.

constellations_other.description: Two of the most striking costumes on the big and small screens embody the glamour of leading First Peoples ladies.

constellations_other.name: Black Power through film and TV
constellations_other.description: The Black Power movement of the late 1960s and early 70s was “the most exciting and dynamic era in modern Indigenous history” according to Aboriginal activist Professor Gary Foley, who gained widespread attention for protests during the time and later leveraged film and TV to fight for Indigenous rights.

end.title: Black Comedy
end.brief_description: Black Comedy is irreverent, politically incorrect and goes where no other series can go. Featuring a fantastic ensemble cast of Indigenous writers and performers, including many special cameo appearances.

constellations_other.name: Aboriginal History Archive
constellations_other.description: The Aboriginal History Archive at Victoria University, led by Gary Foley, is dedicated to the collection and preservation of First Peoples' stories and cultural material. The political activism of the Black Power movement in the 1970s is intersected with representation of Aboriginal actors on screen.

constellations_other.name: Laughing in the face of adversity
constellations_other.description: Comedy has been used by First Nations storytellers as a tool for social change. On our screens, humour invites audiences to engage with stories and prompts them to grapple with ideas that they otherwise might shy away from.

constellations_other.name: Black Power through film and TV
constellations_other.description: The Black Power movement of the late 1960s and early 70s was “the most exciting and dynamic era in modern Indigenous history” according to Aboriginal activist Professor Gary Foley, who gained widespread attention for protests during the time and later leveraged film and TV to fight for Indigenous rights.

links.description: Basically Black was an all-Indigenous comedy show that only ever aired its pilot episode on ABC. Almost 30 years after Basically Black aired, First Nations skit show Black Comedy has gained much success with its hilarious and uncompromising portrayal of what it is like to be Black in Australia.

start.title: Black Comedy
start.brief_description: Black Comedy is irreverent, politically incorrect and goes where no other series can go. Featuring a fantastic ensemble cast of Indigenous writers and performers, including many special cameo appearances.

constellations_other.name: Black Power through film and TV
constellations_other.description: The Black Power movement of the late 1960s and early 70s was “the most exciting and dynamic era in modern Indigenous history” according to Aboriginal activist Professor Gary Foley, who gained widespread attention for protests during the time and later leveraged film and TV to fight for Indigenous rights.

end.title: Bush Mechanics
end.brief_description: David Batty and Francis Jupurrurla Kelly’s Bush Mechanics (2001) became a cult classic and spawned short films, museum exhibitions and even a videogame. This Warlpiri-language miniseries owes its popularity to its distinctive cultural world of Warlpiri humour, music and experience.

constellations_other.name: Alternate histories and futures
constellations_other.description: Sue Ford's Egami reimagines contemporary life through a feminist and colonial lens.

constellations_other.name: Laughing in the face of adversity
constellations_other.description: Comedy has been used by First Nations storytellers as a tool for social change. On our screens, humour invites audiences to engage with stories and prompts them to grapple with ideas that they otherwise might shy away from.

constellations_other.name: Culture and identity on the Australian screen
constellations_other.description: Australian screen culture is distinctive, unexpected, playful and serious when it matters. Indigenous productions make a huge contribution to the unique identity of the Australian moving image.

links.description: Bush Mechanics is a look into the humour and genius of a collective of Walpiri people who miraculously fix cars that seem beyond repair, using only tools found in the Central Australian desert. The show is much loved for its ingenuity and tongue-in-cheek humour.

start.title: Bush Mechanics

This Warlpiri-language miniseries owes its popularity to its distinctive cultural world of Warlpiri humour, music and experience.

end.title: Never Stop Riding
end.brief_description: Alec Baker, Peter Mungkuri and Mr Kunmanara Pompey are three senior artists and respected leaders from Indulkana community on the APY Lands, SA. As young men, they were renowned stockmen and in 2017 they coordinated a men’s camp at the local cattle station. Influenced by their ongoing love for cowboy and western films and country music, they created their own spaghetti western: Never Stop Riding.

constellations_other.name: Laughing in the face of adversity
constellations_other.description: Comedy has been used by First Nations storytellers as a tool for social change. On our screens, humour invites audiences to engage with stories and prompts them to grapple with ideas that they otherwise might shy away from.

links.description: Never Stop Riding is also set in the desert but the cast use horses instead of cars. This short by Peter Mungkuri, Alec Baker and Kunmanara (Jimmy) Pompey embraces the Indulkana community’s history of horse riding, and their love of cowboy and western films.

start.title: Never Stop Riding
start.brief_description: Alec Baker, Peter Mungkuri and Mr Kunmanara Pompey are three senior artists and respected leaders from Indulkana community on the APY Lands, SA. As young men, they were renowned stockmen and in 2017 they coordinated a men’s camp at the local cattle station. Influenced by their ongoing love for cowboy and western films and country music, they created their own spaghetti western: Never Stop Riding.

end.title: Confessions of a Headhunter
end.creator_credit: Archie Weller, Sally Riley and Scarlett Pictures
end.brief_description: In the film, two Noongar men – Frank and Vinnie – travel across the country and seek revenge for the repeated beheading of the statue of their ancestor warrior Yagan.

constellations_other.name: Laughing in the face of adversity
constellations_other.description: Comedy has been used by First Nations storytellers as a tool for social change. On our screens, humour invites audiences to engage with stories and prompts them to grapple with ideas that they otherwise might shy away from.

links.description: A gold heist is central to Never Stop Riding, but in Sally Riley’s Confessions of a Headhunter, two cousins steal bronze statue heads – sawed from figures like Captain Cook – determined to replace colonial monuments and re-instate one that honours their Noongar ancestors.

start.title: Confessions of a Headhunter
start.creator_credit: Archie Weller, Sally Riley and Scarlett Pictures
start.brief_description: In the film, two Noongar men – Frank and Vinnie – travel across the country and seek revenge for the repeated beheading of the statue of their ancestor warrior Yagan.

constellations_other.name: Laughing in the face of adversity
constellations_other.description: Comedy has been used by First Nations storytellers as a tool for social change. On our screens, humour invites audiences to engage with stories and prompts them to grapple with ideas that they otherwise might shy away from.

links.description: Tony Albert’s artwork reinterprets Miley Cyrus’ ‘Wrecking Ball.’ In the film, Albert swings in on a wrecking ball, knocking down monuments of Captain Cook. This comedic work reflects the contemporary movement to remove colonial monuments, questioning how we memorialise some and silence others.

end.title: Kiki and Kitty
end.brief_description: Kiki and Kitty follows the adventures of a young, black woman in a big, white world, where her vagina is a big, black woman AND her best friend.

constellations_other.name: Aboriginal History Archive
constellations_other.description: The Aboriginal History Archive at Victoria University, led by Gary Foley, is dedicated to the collection and preservation of First Peoples' stories and cultural material. The political activism of the Black Power movement in the 1970s is intersected with representation of Aboriginal actors on screen.

constellations_other.description: Two of the most striking costumes on the big and small screens embody the glamour of leading First Peoples ladies.

constellations_other.name: Laughing in the face of adversity
constellations_other.description: Comedy has been used by First Nations storytellers as a tool for social change. On our screens, humour invites audiences to engage with stories and prompts them to grapple with ideas that they otherwise might shy away from.

links.description: One of the writers and stars of Black Comedy, Nakkiah Lui also wrote and starred in Kiki and Kitty. The series follows Kiki as she navigates life with her new frenemy Kitty; the personified version of her vagina, played by Elaine Crombie.

start.title: Kiki and Kitty
start.brief_description: Kiki and Kitty follows the adventures of a young, black woman in a big, white world, where her vagina is a big, black woman AND her best friend.

end.title: Wrong Kind of Black
end.brief_description: From the cops and the crocs of 1960s Palm Island to the blood-spattered dance floors of Melbourne in the 70s, Wrong Kind of Black is the personal story of Boori Monty Pryor (Clarence Ryan) and his brother Paul (Aaron McGrath).

constellations_other.name: Aboriginal History Archive
constellations_other.description: The Aboriginal History Archive at Victoria University, led by Gary Foley, is dedicated to the collection and preservation of First Peoples' stories and cultural material. The political activism of the Black Power movement in the 1970s is intersected with representation of Aboriginal actors on screen.

constellations_other.name: Laughing in the face of adversity
constellations_other.description: Comedy has been used by First Nations storytellers as a tool for social change. On our screens, humour invites audiences to engage with stories and prompts them to grapple with ideas that they otherwise might shy away from.

links.description: Catriona McKenzie, who directed Kiki and Kitty also directed 2018 series Wrong Kind of Black, a hilarious and heartbreaking story of afro bearing, flare wearing DJ Monty Pryor and his brother Paul.
